custom_fields.prerequisite_knowledge:
What prior knowledge must students have in order to be successful in this course? Do not list pre req courses
The course has been completed successfully by students from diverse disciplines, such as psychology, computer science, engineering, and the arts. The principal prerequisite is an interest in the scientific study of human sensing, thinking, and performance. Students with a background in statistics, neuroscience, experimental design, and physics will all find familiar topics, but the course is intended to lift all students up to the level required for the material presented.
custom_fields.assessment_structure: The course grade will be based on a combination of homework, final presentation (usually a paper, but currently under remote teaching a research slide), and 3 tests.
custom_fields.goals: Describe fundamental findings from studies of perceptionRelate functional processes of perception to neural underpinnings and quantitative descriptionUnderstand the commonalities and differences across different sensory modalities vision, audition, touch, smell, tasteInterpret multiple methodologies used to answer basic research issues in perceptionRelate perception to other aspects of human behavior, including attention and actionAppreciate the impact of perceptual processing on everyday life
custom_fields.relevance: Nothing is more relevant than perception: how we see, hear, touch, taste, and smell, and how we represent the world in order to act in it. You should find that the course enhances your everyday experiences.
custom_fields.learning_resources: There is a required text and additional readings posted on Canvas.
custom_fields.extra_time_commitment: There is homework required for every class, which requires reading and preparation.

long_desc: Perception, broadly defined, is the construction of a representation of the external world for purposes of thinking and acting.  Although we often think of perception as the processing of inputs to the sense organs, the world conveyed by the senses is ambiguous, and cognitive and sensory systems interact to interpret it.  In this course, we will examine the sensorylevel mechanisms involved in perception by various sensory modalities, including vision, audition, and touch.  We will learn how sensory coding interacts with topdown processing based on context and prior knowledge and how perception changes with learning and development. We will look at methods of psychophysics, neuroscience, and cognitive psychology.  The goals include not only imparting basic knowledge about perception but also providing new insights into everyday experiences.
name: Perception
